Award.AwardTitle: A quantitative analysis of phenotype in a multicellular prokaryote

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to Syracuse University to undertake a critical step in understanding how a genome encodes an organism's three-dimensional structure. Revealing how each gene in a genome impacts the structure and function of an organism, i.e., "the genotype to phenotype problem" is challenging. Even the simplest organisms self-assemble through fragile, complex, and often poorly understood processes involving many different genes. In this context, the impact of a mutation to any single gene is often too subtle, or too entwined with the function of other genes, to be determined by direct observation. This project will achieve a critical step in overcoming this challenge by constructing a large and well-characterized mutant strain collection based on the genome of Myxococcus xanthus, an organism used to study three dimensional multi-cellular structures. The research will also develop experimental protocols to assign quantitative phenotype profiles that elucidate subtle functional changes linked to each gene, resulting in more accurate and thorough quantification of phenotype in the context of the entire genome, and a genome-scale data set related to function.

In addition to providing a platform for training graduate students, all the strains and data will be made available for education purposes at the undergraduate level. These data will also become integral tools for students in an ongoing upper- division bioinformatics course at Syracuse University, and distributed to faculty from primarily undergraduate institutions to develop similar curricula for their students. In addition, the PI is engaging with local high school teachers to bring these data into their classrooms as an introduction to the genotype-to-phenotype problem and opportunities in life science in the post-genomic era. Information on this project can be found at: www.welchlab.org

POR.DRECONTENT:
The instructions for the developmental phenotype of an organism are encoded in its genome, and the execution of those instructions is affected by an organism’s environment. Reverse engineering the process of development requires creating an accurate timeline of phenotypic stages and understanding the function of all the relevant genetic elements in the manifestation of each stage. A common type of experiment aimed at establishing a connection between an organism’s genotype and phenotype involves examining the phenotypic impact of mutations. Hypotheses connecting phenotypic stages and functional genetics can be extrapolated from this kind of initial data.

Our long-term goal is to generate a very large set of this kind of data for all the genetic elements in a developmental model organism and use it to construct a comprehensive network of associations between its genome and phenome, but there is a significant obstacle; most mutations result in no observable changes in phenotype. We hypothesized that we were not looking carefully enough, and that we could overcome this obstacle through a more detailed and systematic approach to phenotyping. We chose the bacterium Myxococcus xanthus because it is simpler than eukaryotic developmental models, and yet it grows as a true multicellular biofilm that develops into fruiting bodies when starved. We built a cluster of 100 microscopes to record the developmental phenotype of thousands of mutant strains, and we examined every phenotypic feature we thought we could quantify. We then began systematically recording the development of an expanded mutant strain collection. Our ability to observe the phenotypic impact of mutation rose from ~10% to >65% of strains.

We therefore believe we have largely achieved our goal of quantifying the M. xanthus developmental phenotype and building an initial low-resolution genotype-to-phenotype network. We have identified changes in phenotype that cluster with mutations in homologous groups of genes. We have determined that what were once thought to be unusual mutant phenotypes are common. We have observed mutant phenotypes that current mathematical models would say were impossible, and these findings forced us to rethink the timeline of phenotypic stages. We have data in support of at least two new signal transduction systems, one of which seems to generate a new kind of propagating wave.
